Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation: Criminal Offenders, Access to Resources, and Recidivism

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
Many of those under court supervision after a criminal conviction have limited resources, due to issues such as poverty, disability, unemployment, living in high crime neighborhoods, and homelessness. While members of a person's social networks can provide access to such resources, women offenders have especially limited network support, in part due to the stigmatizing effects of a conviction. This project will conduct interviews with female felons on parole or probation as a way of analyzing whether certain personal networks, including experts, problem solving help, and personal support, influence rates of recidivism. Consequently, this project will consider whether policies and practices, some of which prohibit offenders from interacting with certain people such as other ex-offenders, influence offenders' social networks, access to resources, and recidivism.

This project will apply egocentric social network analysis theories and techniques to understand the structure and composition of women offenders? personal networks and access to key resources. The project will seek to determine the association between access to resources and the likelihood of offenders' recidivism. To do so, the project will interview 160 women offenders, 80 of whom were on parole and 80 on probation, from 16 Michigan counties that include rural, suburban, small town, and urban areas. Data will be collected on offender characteristics, network member characteristics, tie/relationship characteristics, and overall network characteristics. De-identified data from the project will be made publicly available. The project will test single-level and multilevel models to ascertain the effects of offenders' social networks on recidivism.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Outcomes:

 Women are growing in representation in the criminal justice system, but are understudied. This dissertation research focused on 160 female offenders? access to resources from their entire networks and 1313 semiregular interaction partners (i.e., friends, family members, coworkers). Specifically, the research aimed to: 1) describe women?s social support networks and access to social capital, which is the potential resources available from one?s network, and 2) identify participant (e.g., financial hardship, limited education), network member (e.g., age, gender, criminal history), tie (e.g., closeness, frequency of contact), and network characteristics (e.g., density, proportion kin) that are associated with access to needed resources. The dissertation included two studies.  The first study examined women?s access to resources from individuals who they ?know? based on 26 questions (a resource generator) that measures the types of resources available from network members. Findings from the analysis identified the predictors of access to two types of social capital, political social capital and personal and problem-solving capital. The second study focused on social capital available from each network member and the structure and composition of women?s networks. Multilevel regression models were tested to predict access to resources from specific network members.

In the first study, on average, women had access to nearly three-quarters of the 26 resource generator items, but they had resource deficits in political social capital (i.e., access to elected officials, someone who works at City Hall). Women who reported high employment and financial needs (i.e., unemployed, unable to pay bills without help from family or friends) and women who had recently been arrested were less likely to have access to political social capital. Women who had attained higher levels of education were more likely to have access to personal and problem-solving social capital.

In the second study, on average, women possessed eight semiregular interaction partners. One-third of network members had previously been involved with the law and many of them were substance users. On average, crime-involved and/or substance-abusing ties accounted for approximately half of women?s access to social capital. Networks were moderately dense, with some members interacting with each other, and comprised of mostly women. Tests of the association between participant characteristics and resources access suggest that older participants and those with higher employment and financial needs were least likely to be tied to individuals who provided access to social capital. Network members who were older in age, employed, and emotionally close to the participant were particularly helpful in providing women access to resources. Finally, a test of an interaction effect between network characteristics revealed that for women with loosely-knit networks of people who did not interact with each other (i.e., low density), increases in the proportion of kinship ties within the network was associated with reduced access to social capital.  Thus, low density networks with most people being relatives offered the least social capital.

Intellectual merit:

The dissertation research is unique in its application of egocentric (i.e., focused on the individual) social network analysis theory and techniques in a criminal justice context. Social network theorists posit increased resource access as resulting from network characteristics such as network members' closeness and or proportional characteristics (e.g., percent female). This project is the first to test these concepts with a female community-based, correctional population. Additionally, criminological frameworks and research emphasize the importance of social capital for desistance from crime but fail to examine why deficits exist in networks and how differences among offenders' semiregular interaction partners are related to resource access. Besides filling gaps in knowledge, the project's design improves upon prior methodological limitations (i.e., failure to elicit information on negative social ties, data collection methods that do not identify all network members), presents the social network questions as the focus of the research interview to reduce risk of participant fatigue, and expands beyond prior core network research that considers just five to ten kin or friends.

Broader Impacts:

The findings from the dissertation research provide a foundation for discussing contextually sensitive correctional supervision requirements. Broadly, it is evident that relationships are complex. For example, about half of network members that provided access to resources had previously been involved with the law and/or used substances. Considering the ease of access to substances in high-crime, economically disadvantaged neighborhoods and the high-concentration of individuals who have felony convictions in the neighborhoods where women offenders tend to reside, prohibiting offenders from interacting with people who have committed felonies may not be conducive to them receiving needed support and successfully navigating supervision requirements. Instead, the findings point to a more nuanced approach to serving crime-involved individuals, that helps them strengthen important ties and escape those that are detrimental, and that provides offenders with insight into the construction of network ties that are most likely to provide support.
